speaker: Daphne
text: Hello

speaker: Niles
text: Hey.

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah, the weekend warriors have returned.

speaker: Daphne
text: Yeah.  You better watch out, Dr. Crane, I'm getting pretty good at kickboxing.

speaker: Niles
text: It's true.  She hits so hard they're calling her "The British Pound."

speaker: Daphne
text: You hit pretty hard yourself there, "Nails." [_She kisses him._] I'm going to hop in the shower.

speaker: Frasier
text: "Nails"?

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, you scratch one guy... Oh, my electrolytes are plummeting. Care to join me in a sherry?

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah, actually, I'd love to, Niles, but I'm off to see Dr. Tewksbury.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, I didn't realize your mentor was still in town.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, and because of it, I've been the fortunate recipient of some informal therapy.  It's really been quite enlightening. You know, I consider myself lucky to be in the hands of such a master.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, I'm happy for you, Frasier.  He is a gifted psychiatrist, even if I don't share your god-like worship of him.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, I simply have a healthy respect for the man, Niles. It's hardly worship.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, please.  You're one step away from seeing his image appear in a tortilla.

speaker: Daphne
text: Niles, thank heavens you're still here!

speaker: Niles
text: What's wrong?

speaker: Daphne
text: You can't go to Nervosa today.

speaker: Niles
text: Why not?

speaker: Daphne
text: I just had a psychic vision that something bad's going to happen to you.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, come on, Daphne...

speaker: Daphne
text: Niles, I'm serious!  I know you don't believe in visions, but it's important to me.  Promise me you won't go.

speaker: Niles
text: All right, if it means that much to you, I won't go.  I'll go straight home.

speaker: Daphne
text: Thank you.  I feel much better. [_She gives him a kiss._] I'll see you later.  _She heads to her room again.  Frasier opens the door and Niles turns to leave with him._

speaker: Frasier
text: Wow, that was scary.

speaker: Niles
text: Don't tell me you believe in that stuff...

speaker: Frasier
text: No, I meant the way she can manipulate you like that.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, please, I was just being diplomatic.

speaker: Frasier
text: Tell me, is it difficult to kickbox without a spine?

speaker: Niles
text: You're gonna find out.  _They exit.  FADE OUT.  Scene 2 - Cafe Nervosa  Fade in.  Frasier is sitting at a table, drinking coffee and reading. Roz comes in with some bags._

speaker: Roz
text: Hello, Frasier.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, hi, Roz.  Oh, been on a shopping spree, I see.

speaker: Roz
text: Yes, Alice is been visiting her grandmother for the week. So, I finally have some time to myself.  I tell you, it's great shopping without her pulling down a display rack.  Not only that, I actually woke up today without someone jumping on the bed and sticking her little fingers up my nose.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes.

speaker: Roz
text: And I didn't have to spend half the morning combing knots out of that little girl's curls...

speaker: Frasier
text: [_hands her his cell phone_] Give Alice my love.

speaker: Roz
text: [_getting up_] Thank you, I will.

speaker: Niles
text: Psst, Frasier.  Can you get me a latte?

speaker: Frasier
text: Why don't you just get it yourself, Niles?  Oh, that's right: it's bad moogambo for you to enter.

speaker: Niles
text: You know I promised Daphne.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_rising_] Yes, yes, and woe betide he who disobeyeth the oracle!

speaker: Niles
text: All right, all right, wait.  Maybe if I get it to go, and don't sit down, I won't actually be breaking my promise to Daphne.

speaker: Frasier
text: Step aside everybody, big set of onions coming through!

speaker: Niles
text: Latte to go, please.

speaker: Tewksbury
text: Hello, Frasier.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dr. Tewksbury.  Well, gosh, this is quite a surprise.  What are you doing here?

speaker: Tewksbury
text: Well, I've heard you mention how good their coffee is here, I thought I'd give it a try.  May I join you?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, yes, of course.  I'm terribly sorry.  Oh, Roz, meet Dr. Tewksbury.  Dr. Tewksbury, this is my producer Roz Doyle. And my brother Niles.  Niles, Dr. Tewksbury.

speaker: Niles
text: Hello, how do you do?

speaker: Tewksbury
text: I don't believe we've ever met, but I seem to recall reading a fascinating paper of yours recently.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, yes, it was probably the one about phobias.  Oh, can't sit, can't sit.

speaker: Frasier
text: It's a long story.  Anyway, Dr. Tewksbury, I was just wondering, did you happen to read the article on behavior modification in...

speaker: Tewksbury
text: Now, Frasier, let's not talk shop.  You don't want to bore Roz.

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, it's all just white noise to me, now. [_Tewksbury laughs_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, all right.  Niles, please, would you stop hovering and please sit down?

speaker: Niles
text: All right.  What could it hurt?

speaker: Daphne
text: Niles!

speaker: Niles
text: Daphne!

speaker: Daphne
text: How could you come down here?  You broke your promise!

speaker: Niles
text: And my patella!

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, nothing bad would have happened if you'd paid attention to my premonition!

speaker: Niles
text: Well, actually, nothing bad would have happened if you hadn't shown up.

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, it wouldn't have not happened had I not shown up.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, it wouldn't not have happened if you hadn't not shown up!

speaker: Daphne
text: And I wouldn't have shown up had I not known that you wouldn't have been able to not come down here!

speaker: Niles
text: Well, I'm not... not... not... what?

speaker: Daphne
text: My point exactly!  You don't listen.

speaker: Niles
text: Daphne!

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, Niles, you all right?

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, no, I've aggravated my old bossa nova injury.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, perhaps I better drive you.  I'm sorry, Dr. Tewksbury.

speaker: Tewksbury
text: I understand.

speaker: Frasier
text: Bye, Roz.

speaker: Roz
text: Bye!

speaker: Tewksbury
text: Well, what was that all about?

speaker: Roz
text: Well, she thinks she's psychic, but he doesn't believe her.

speaker: Tewksbury
text: Well, no matter who's right or wrong, Niles needs to set up stricter boundaries with his patients.  I learned that from years of practice.

speaker: Roz
text: No, no.  She's not his patient, she's his girlfriend.

speaker: Tewksbury
text: Oh, well in that case, no matter who's right or wrong, HE's wrong.  I learned that from years of marriage.   **DON'T FORGET THE GEIGER COUNTER AND THE DIVINING ROD**

speaker: Frasier
text: Is there anything I can get you, Niles?  Perhaps a cold pack, perhaps?

speaker: Niles
text: No, no.  If Daphne ever comes out of her room, I'll just use her icy stare.  Frasier, if you don't mind, I'm going to have to cancel on the opera tonight.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Niles, you know I hate going to the opera alone. Throwing a woman's shawl over the seat next to me and glancing expectantly back at the ladies room all night.

speaker: Niles
text: You do that?

speaker: Frasier
text: No!

speaker: Niles
text: Hey, why don't you ask Dr. Tewksbury if he'd like to go?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, no.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, come on.  Ever since his divorce I'm sure he's anxious to get out of the house.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, we're in a quasi-therapeutic relationship right now. Truth be told, I was actually a little uncomfortable socializing with him at Nervosa.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, I understand.  You don't want to see the wizard behind the curtain.  Everyone needs an idol, someone who represents a higher plateau of truth and knowledge.

speaker: Frasier
text: Very insightful, Niles.  For so many years I must have represented that plateau to you.

speaker: Niles
text: Thank you, Frasier, laughter is indeed the best medicine.

speaker: Niles
text: [_rising_] Oh, Daphne.  My knee's feeling much better.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_deadpan_] Oh, good.

speaker: Niles
text: Well I hope she doesn't expect me to run in there after her.

speaker: Frasier
text: Good for you, Niles!

speaker: Niles
text: With this knee I can only hobble.  _And he proceeds to hobble in there after her.  Reset to: the kitchen as he enters._

speaker: Niles
text: Daphne, I'm sorry.

speaker: Daphne
text: Are you sorry for breaking your promise or for not believing me?

speaker: Niles
text: I'm sorry for breaking my promise.

speaker: Daphne
text: So you still don't believe I had a premonition?

speaker: Niles
text: Well, it wasn't a premonition...

speaker: Daphne
text: It certainly was!  I told you if you went to Nervosa, something bad would happen, and you hurt your knee.  What more proof do you need?

speaker: Niles
text: Something a little more scientific than that, I'm afraid.

speaker: Daphne
text: You need scientific proof?  Well, I think we can do something about that.

speaker: Niles
text: What do you mean?

speaker: Daphne
text: There are people around who do this sort of research.

speaker: Niles
text: Are those people here now?

speaker: Daphne
text: No!  I'm talking about legitimate professionals.

speaker: Niles
text: All right, all right.  But it has to be a real scientist. Not some huckster who comes here with crystals and a ghost- o-meter.

speaker: Daphne
text: As long as you have an open mind.  And it's pronounced "ghost-ah-meters".

speaker: Niles
text: I'm glad we worked this out.

speaker: Daphne
text: Me too.

speaker: Niles
text: And now that we've made up, maybe we could...

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, I guess we know who's not psychic.   **THE DOCTOR MAKES A HOUSE CALL**   _Fade in.  There is a knock at the door.  Roz, in her nightgown and robe, opens the door to reveal Frasier._

speaker: Roz
text: Frasier!  I thought you were the pizza guy.

speaker: Frasier
text: I thought we were writing promos tonight.  You forgot, didn't you?

speaker: Roz
text: NO!  Yes.  I'm sorry. _Dr. Tewksbury comes in from the other room wearing one of Roz's short silk robes._

speaker: Tewksbury
text: Pizza!  We're gonna have pizza!  We... [_stops and puts on his glasses_] Frasier!  Hello.  What are you doing here?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, just, ah... wearing clothes.

speaker: Tewksbury
text: Oh, right.

speaker: Roz
text: Frasier brought over some work from the office.

speaker: Tewksbury
text: Ah.  I'll just... go get dressed.

speaker: Frasier
text: I've gone blind.  And ten seconds too late.  So, since when have you and Dr. Tewksbury been seeing each other?

speaker: Roz
text: Well, uh, the other day at Nervosa we really hit it off after you left and he asked me out for dinner and... we've been out every night since.

speaker: Frasier
text: Really?  Well, I must say I'm a bit surprised.

speaker: Roz
text: Why?  He's smart, very insightful. and he's such a great listener.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, well, I'm happy for you, Roz.  It's just a little difficult imagining the two of you together.

speaker: Roz
text: You don't think I can appreciate a sophisticated man?  You know, it's not just about sex for me, Frasier.

speaker: Tewksbury
text: Uh, do you have a stepladder?  My pants are stuck in the ceiling fan.  _Roz and Frasier share a look and, realizing neither is really the winner, Frasier walks off and Roz closes the door.  FADE OUT._

speaker: Tewksbury
text: Frasier, listen.  Before we begin, I hope it wasn't too awkward seeing me with Roz last night.

speaker: Frasier
text: Not at all.  Well, it was just a little... jarring to see you out of context that way.  But your personal life is your business.  Speaking of which, let's, let's get down to business: The Crane mind!

speaker: Tewksbury
text: Yes, let us.

speaker: Tewksbury
text: Now, last time we had just broached the subject of your father's expectations and their effect on your early adulthood. _Frasier tries to control his upset at the image of the robed doctor, unsuccessfully.  He grows more uncomfortable as Tewksbury sits on the desk and puts a hand behind his head._

speaker: Tewksbury
text: As we know, the internalization of a parent's moral code is crucial to the development of a superego.  And considering the strict nature of your father's strictness...  Frasier, is everything all right?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, yes, of course.  Please, continue.

speaker: Tewksbury
text: Well you must admit that having a father whose very job is the enforcement of the moral code, would lead to an overdeveloped superego.  _As he leans across the desk, the image of him in the robe once again appears to Frasier._

speaker: Tewksbury
text: I believe I have a paper on this subject.  _He goes to a filing cabinet and leans down to the bottom drawer, making Frasier VERY uncomfortable._

speaker: Tewksbury
text: It's right here.  _Frasier tries to look away and back, but the image won't go away. FADE OUT.  End of Act 1  Act 2  Scene 1 - Frasier's Apartment_  _Fade in.  Martin is sitting in his chair, reading.  Frasier comes in the front door._

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, hey, Dad.

speaker: Martin
text: Hey.

speaker: Frasier
text: How was your day?

speaker: Martin
text: Why don't you just tell me what happened to you?

speaker: Frasier
text: What are you talking about?

speaker: Martin
text: Well, you know how my day goes: play with Eddie, watch TV, do my stretches.  You only ask so I'll ask you about your day, so I'm askin'.

speaker: Frasier
text: I am hurt.  You're my father, of course I care about your day.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, well, uh, I played with Eddie, watched TV, did my stretches.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, good.

speaker: Martin
text: So, how was...

speaker: Frasier
text: I just came from Dr. Tewksbury.  Throughout the entire session, I just couldn't focus on anything he was saying.

speaker: Martin
text: Wasn't he talkin' about you?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, yes, but recently I saw him in... well, a less than dignified light.  And ever since, I've just found it impossible to take him seriously.

speaker: Martin
text: I know exactly what you're talking about.  In Korea, I had this commanding officer, Lieutenant Franks.  I would have followed that guy into the gates of hell.  I saw him a few years later, he was flippin' hamburgers in a fast food place. That was hard to handle.  I mean this guy took me under his wing and molded me.

speaker: Frasier
text: Like a mentor?

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, exactly.  He always used to say that one day he'd be takin' orders from me.  I just never thought it'd be for extra onions.

speaker: Frasier
text: So how did you handle it?

speaker: Martin
text: Well, I just realized it was my problem, not his.  And I wasn't gonna let it erase all that he'd meant to me.  So I marched right back into that kitchen and saluted him. And after we were talkin' a while, I realized nothin' had changed.  He was still the same hard-chargin' man's man who wasn't afraid to get his hands dirty.  Which is why I never ate there again.  _Frasier and Martin share a laugh.  Daphne and Niles come in from her room._

speaker: Niles
text: Uh, if you two don't mind, Daphne's psychic evaluator is on the way over and we'd like to use the living room.

speaker: Martin
text: [_rising_] Ooh, fine by me.  That stuff creeps me out anyway.

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles I still can't believe you ever agreed to this.  Those tests are based on nothing more than subjective evidence and lucky guesses.

speaker: Daphne
text: Yes, nothing at all like the subjective evidence and lucky guesses psychiatry is based on.

speaker: Martin
text: [_smugly_] Thank you.

speaker: Niles
text: Don't worry, I will thoroughly appraise the examiner and his testing methods.

speaker: Frasier
text: Good luck.

speaker: Niles
text: That'll be him.

speaker: Niles
text: Come in.  I'm Dr. Niles Crane, this is Daphne Moon.

speaker: Daphne
text: Hello.

speaker: Morey
text: Hello, I'm Dr. Sheldon Morey.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, doctor?  Doctor of...?

speaker: Morey
text: Spookology! [_then_] Kidding.  That's just what most people expect.  Actually I'm a professor of psychiatry at Seattle University.

speaker: Niles
text: Really?  Please, have a seat.

speaker: Morey
text: Thank you.

speaker: Niles
text: So, hmm, you're more of a debunker.

speaker: Morey
text: Well, no, not at all.  Actually, I apply scientific principles to the search for paranormal phenomena.  Believe me, nothing would make me happier than discovering a legitimate psychic.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, so, then you've never found one.

speaker: Morey
text: Well, if by "psychic" you mean people with above-normal prescience, then a few.  If you mean somebody who could beat the house in Vegas, then no.  I thought I had one for a while, but, uh... no.

speaker: Niles
text: So, Daphne, do you still want to go through with this?

speaker: Daphne
text: I'm ready if you are.

speaker: Niles
text: All right, Doctor, she's all yours.

speaker: Morey
text: Great.  Now, I've got a card...

speaker: Daphne
text: Ace of spades!

speaker: Morey
text: ...with my office and fax number on it.

speaker: Daphne
text: And your address!

speaker: Morey
text: Correct.  _He hands the card to Niles.  DISSOLVE TO: later,  Daphne and Morey are at the dining table and he's giving her a standard test with cards._

speaker: Daphne
text: Star...  Circle.

speaker: Morey
text: And finally?

speaker: Daphne
text: Circle.

speaker: Morey
text: That's it.  That was your final test.

speaker: Daphne
text: And I'm psychic, right?

speaker: Morey
text: Well, first we have to compare your results to those of the rest of the control group.  It'll just take me a few minutes to run these numbers, okay?

speaker: Niles
text: So?  How do you think you did?

speaker: Daphne
text: I think I did pretty well on the cards.  The premonition test was a little tricky, but all in all I was in the zone.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, we'll soon find out.

speaker: Morey
text: You know, Daphne, I'm always curious: when was it that you first suspected you had psychic ability?

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, years ago, when I was a little girl.  Grammy Moon first saw the gift in me.  See, I was a girl in a house full of boys, which I hated, until Grammy told me that only Moon women had second sight.  She had it, her mother had it and so on. After that, I noticed I could sense things before they happened, sort of like a secret power.  Anyway, it's just always been a part of who I am.

speaker: Morey
text: I see.  Well, we have your results.

speaker: Daphne
text: All right.  I don't know why I'm a bit nervous.

speaker: Morey
text: So, Daphne, from what I see here...

speaker: Niles
text: Wait, uh...  Wait.  I don't think we should this, I don't want to know.

speaker: Daphne
text: What do you mean?

speaker: Niles
text: I'm sorry, I think this was a bad idea.

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, I thought you wanted scientific proof.

speaker: Niles
text: I changed my mind.  I don't need a stranger telling me... anything about who you are.  I want us to get to know each other on our own.  Over time.

speaker: Daphne
text: I knew you were going to say that!

speaker: Niles
text: You did?

speaker: Daphne
text: No, but I loved hearing it.

speaker: Daphne
text: I'm sorry, Dr. Morey, we wasted your time.

speaker: Morey
text: It's okay.  The dog told me a couple of funny jokes while we were waiting.

speaker: Morey
text: I'm kidding.  They weren't that funny.   **THE BIG CITY PROVES TOO MUCH FOR PETERSON**   _Fade in.  Frasier is again sitting in front of Tewksbury's desk, receiving analysis._

speaker: Tewksbury
text: All right, Frasier, let's start with our last session. As I recall, you were having difficulty getting rid of a certain image in your mind?

speaker: Frasier
text: That is correct.

speaker: Tewksbury
text: Well, perhaps we should confront that.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, dear lord, I assumed that was Roz's.

speaker: Tewksbury
text: It is.  I was at her apartment this morning, I started thinking about your issue with the robe, and I decided to bring it with me. [_He puts the robe on._] Now Frasier, you consider me a competent psychiatrist, don't you?

speaker: Frasier
text: Of course I do.

speaker: Tewksbury
text: Does seeing me dressed like this diminish that?

speaker: Frasier
text: No, of course not.  It's just, well... I know, on a conscious level, that the garment does not change who you are.  But on, on an unconscious level, I'm all weirded out!  You're my mentor, and you're wearing Roz's robe.

speaker: Tewksbury
text: I'm still the same person.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, but, it's Roz's robe.

speaker: Tewksbury
text: And what does Roz's robe signify to you?

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz.

speaker: Tewksbury
text: Then maybe this isn't about you and me.  Maybe this is about your relationship with Roz.

speaker: Tewksbury
text: Seeing me dressed like this brings up deep feelings.  Don't be afraid of those feelings, go with them. [_He notices the student._] Ah, Peterson.  Here for your make-up test?

speaker: Peterson
text: I was.  But I'll just take the D. _He leaves.  Frasier and Tewksbury both realize there's not a lot they can say.  FADE OUT._  Scene 3 - Roz's Apartment  _Fade in.  There is a knock at the door, Roz answers it to reveal Frasier._

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, Frasier.

speaker: Frasier
text: You got a minute?

speaker: Roz
text: We're not supposed to be working, are we?  'Cause I'm kinda busy right now.

speaker: Frasier
text: It's not about work.

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, come on in.

speaker: Roz
text: Have a seat.

speaker: Frasier
text: Thanks.

speaker: Frasier
text: Listen, uh, something's been troubling me ever since I saw Dr. Tewksbury in your robe and, uh, at first I thought it was about the toppling of a hero, but I've since discovered that it's really about you.

speaker: Roz
text: Let me guess: I'm not good enough for your precious mentor.

speaker: Frasier
text: No, that's not it, Roz.  Uh...  When you were describing what attracted you to Dr. Tewksbury, I couldn't help thinking "That very well could have been me."

speaker: Roz
text: So?

speaker: Frasier
text: So, Roz, I've known you for, what, eight years now.  And in that time I've seen you date hundreds of...

speaker: Roz
text: Careful!

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, dozens of men.  Yet you never showed any interest in me.  Well, except for that one drunken flirtation at the station retreat.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, anyway, I assumed it was because I wasn't your type. Then I see you drawn to someone who's similar to me.

speaker: Roz
text: You're jealous?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, no, not jealous, not exactly.  It's more along the lines of "Why everybody else and not me?"

speaker: Roz
text: Frasier, did you ever stop to think there may be something special about not being picked?

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz, that didn't work when I was cut from pee-wee football, it's not gonna work now.

speaker: Roz
text: Okay, I'll be honest with you.  When we first started working together, I had a little crush on you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Really?

speaker: Roz
text: Yeah, sure.  I mean, you were handsome and sophisticated and you had your French suits and your Italian shoes...

speaker: Frasier
text: Actually, it was vice-versa, but go on, go on.

speaker: Roz
text: But you were coming off this divorce, and you were my boss, and the whole thing was just too weird, so I never acted on it.

speaker: Frasier
text: And you were right.  You were.  Anyway, it's nice to know how you felt.  Thanks.

speaker: Roz
text: Sure.

speaker: Frasier
text: So, just for the record, though: you did have the hots for me?

speaker: Roz
text: Yes, yes.

speaker: Frasier
text: You're not just saying that?

speaker: Roz
text: No.  But, can you imagine the two of us together?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, gosh, no. [_rising_] Strange idea, isn't it?

speaker: Roz
text: Really strange.

speaker: Frasier
text: Gosh, it's really hard to picture, isn't it?  Of course, I mean, it wouldn't be your problem.  It would be all me, trust me, all me.  I mean, you're a perfectly wonderful person.

speaker: Roz
text: What are you doing?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I'm just saying how great you are.

speaker: Roz
text: No, you're giving me the "It's not you, it's me" speech.  If anyone should be giving that speech, it's me, not you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, whatever you have to tell yourself, Roz.

speaker: Roz
text: All right, get out!

speaker: Frasier
text: Sounds to me like somebody still has a soft spot for the ol' boss man.

speaker: Roz
text: OUT!
